legal_tax.title: Legal & Tax Terms
legal_tax.description: Spanish legal and tax terminology for property transactions

terms.definition: A tax identification number required for all foreigners conducting financial transactions in Spain, including property purchases, opening bank accounts, and signing contracts.
The Spanish tax identification number for residents. For Spanish nationals, this is the same as their DNI number.
The physical residence card issued to non-EU foreigners living in Spain, containing their NIE number and residence permit details.
Annual municipal property tax in Spain, typically 0.4% to 1.1% of the cadastral value. Paid yearly to the local town hall.
Transfer tax paid when purchasing resale properties in Spain. In Andalusia, this is 7% of the declared purchase price.
Stamp duty tax in Spain, charged at 1.2% in Andalusia on new-build properties and mortgages.
Value Added Tax charged on new-build properties in Spain at 10% of the purchase price (21% for commercial properties).

terms.full_name: Impuesto sobre el Incremento de Valor de los Terrenos
terms.definition: Municipal capital gains tax on the increased land value since the last sale. Traditionally paid by the seller but negotiable.
The official administrative value of a property used to calculate IBI and other taxes. Usually significantly lower than market value.
The Spanish property registry that maintains records of all properties including boundaries, size, and cadastral values.

terms.full_name: Impuesto sobre la Renta de No Residentes
terms.definition: Non-resident income tax in Spain. Property owners must pay annually even if not renting out (imputed income). Rate is 19% for EU residents, 24% for others.
The Spanish tax form used by non-residents to declare and pay income tax on Spanish property, including rental income and imputed income.
A tax representative in Spain who handles tax obligations for non-residents, including filing Modelo 210 and receiving official communications.
Annual tax on net assets exceeding €700,000 (threshold varies by region). Rates range from 0.2% to 3.5% depending on total wealth.

property.title: Property Terms
property.description: Real estate and property-specific terminology in Spain

terms.definition: The public deed of sale signed before a notary that officially transfers property ownership. This document is then registered in the Property Registry.
An official extract from the Property Registry showing current ownership, charges, and encumbrances on a property. Essential for due diligence.
The Spanish Property Registry where all property ownership and charges are officially recorded. Registration provides legal protection for ownership.
A public official who authenticates the property sale deed, verifies identities, and ensures legal requirements are met. Notary fees are regulated by government.
Purchasing a property before construction is complete, typically at a lower price with staged payments. Buyers benefit from BFA bank guarantees protecting deposits.
A newly constructed property being sold for the first time. Subject to 10% IVA instead of 7% ITP, plus 1.2% AJD stamp duty.
A previously owned property being sold by its current owner. Subject to 7% ITP transfer tax in Andalusia instead of IVA.
A planned residential development or gated community, typically with shared amenities like pools, gardens, and 24-hour security.
Monthly or quarterly fees paid to maintain shared areas in an urbanization or apartment building, including pools, gardens, lifts, and security.
The community of property owners in a building or urbanization who collectively manage shared areas and make decisions at AGMs.
A reservation or deposit contract in Spain. Arras penitenciales allows buyer to withdraw losing the deposit, or seller to withdraw paying double.
Official certificate confirming a new-build property meets all building regulations and is fit for habitation. Required to connect utilities.
Mandatory certificate rating a property's energy efficiency from A (most efficient) to G. Required for all property sales and rentals.
A unique 20-character code identifying a property in the Spanish Catastro system. Essential for tax purposes and property identification.

visa_residency.title: Visa & Residency Terms
visa_residency.description: Immigration and residency terminology for Spain

terms.definition: A Spanish residence permit granted to non-EU investors who purchase property worth €500,000 or more. Allows residence and Schengen travel without requiring minimum stay.
A residence visa for non-EU nationals who can prove sufficient passive income (approximately €28,800/year) without working in Spain.
Spanish visa for remote workers employed by or running businesses outside Spain. Requires minimum income of approximately €28,800/year from non-Spanish sources.
Registration with your local town hall confirming your address in Spain. Required for many administrative procedures including healthcare access.
Official permission to reside in Spain. EU citizens register after 3 months; non-EU citizens require a visa and residence card (TIE).
Non-EU visitors can stay in the Schengen area for a maximum of 90 days within any 180-day period without a visa. Applies to UK citizens post-Brexit.
A group of 27 European countries with no internal border controls. Spain is a member, allowing free movement within the zone.
Permanent residence status granted after 5 years of legal residence in Spain. Provides same rights as Spanish citizens except voting.
The percentage of property value that a bank will lend as a mortgage. Spanish banks typically offer 60-70% LTV for non-residents, 80% for residents.
A Spanish mortgage loan secured against property. Non-residents can obtain mortgages from Spanish banks with appropriate documentation.
The benchmark interest rate for euro lending between European banks. Variable rate mortgages in Spain are typically priced as Euribor plus a margin.
A mortgage where the interest rate remains constant throughout the term. Provides payment certainty but typically starts higher than variable rates.
A mortgage where the interest rate is reviewed periodically (usually annually) based on Euribor plus a fixed margin.
The annual rental income expressed as a percentage of property value. Costa del Sol typically sees 4-6% for long-term rentals, 8-12% for holiday lets.
Tax on profit from selling property in Spain. Rates are 19% on first €6,000, then 21-28% on higher amounts. Various allowances may apply.
For off-plan purchases, developers must provide bank guarantees protecting buyer deposits until completion or refunding if the project fails.
Legal document authorizing another person (typically a lawyer) to act on your behalf for property transactions. Essential for remote purchases.

location.title: Location Terms
location.description: Geographic and location-specific terminology for Costa del Sol

terms.definition: The 150km Mediterranean coastline in southern Spain stretching from Málaga to Gibraltar. Known for 320+ days of sunshine annually and popular with international buyers.
The autonomous community in southern Spain that includes the Costa del Sol. Has its own tax rates and property regulations.
The prestigious stretch between Marbella town and Puerto Banús, home to some of the most exclusive properties, hotels, and beach clubs on the Costa del Sol.
The coastal stretch between San Pedro and Estepona, offering similar beachfront lifestyle to Marbella's Golden Mile at more accessible prices.
The famous luxury marina in Marbella known for superyachts, designer boutiques, and upscale nightlife. A landmark of Costa del Sol's jet-set lifestyle.
Traditional Spanish village, often a 'pueblo blanco' (white village) with whitewashed buildings and narrow streets. Many are protected historical areas.
A beachfront bar or restaurant serving food and drinks, typically specializing in fresh seafood and paella. A quintessential Costa del Sol experience.
The beachfront promenade found in most Costa del Sol towns, ideal for walking, cycling, and enjoying the Mediterranean views.

process.title: Process Terms
process.description: Property buying process and procedural terminology

terms.definition: The investigation process before purchasing property, including legal checks on ownership, planning permissions, debts, and building compliance.
The final stage of property purchase when buyer and seller sign the deed before a notary, funds are transferred, and keys are handed over.
An initial payment (typically €3,000-€10,000) to take a property off the market while contracts are prepared. Usually deducted from final price.
A binding private purchase agreement between buyer and seller, typically signed after due diligence with a 10% deposit paid.
The legal process of transferring property ownership from seller to buyer, including all documentation, checks, and registrations.
A Spanish administrative services company that handles paperwork and bureaucratic procedures like NIE applications, tax filings, and utility connections.
